title: How to Draw a Girl in a Ponytail

steps.headline: Draw an oval for the face.
Decide where the ponytail ring will be placed.
steps.description: All hair strands will emanate from this spot. High ponytails are typically tight to help them stay in place. Low ponytails may be tight or loose.

steps.headline: Draw the outline of the ponytail coming from the ring.
steps.description: It will "puff out" to be wider than the ring in most cases, especially if the hair is wavy or curly.

steps.headline: Fill in the details of the ponytail.
steps.description: Sketch with a loose wrist and elbow to help keep the flow. Remember that your lines don't have to be parallel or even. A little variety is a good thing. Use curved lines for straight or wavy hair. (Yes, even if the hair is very straight.)

steps.headline: Break it up near the end if her hair is straight or wavy.
steps.description: Ponytails rarely end in a point unless they are soaking wet. Sketch smaller lines at the tip of her ponytail, remembering to keep them curved and uneven. This will help her hair look more natural. Skip this step if she has puffy curls (e.g. Afro-textured).

steps.headline: Draw strands of hair on her head flowing towards the ponytail ring.
steps.description: They can be uneven, especially if the ponytail is loose or sloppy.

steps.headline: Make it a little messy.
steps.description: Draw some lines that diverge from the general direction. Inside the ponytail, hair is going to flow in slightly different directions. Some hair will escape from the ponytail, especially over time and if the girl has been active. Common places for hair to escape include around the face (since this hair is farthest from the ring) and at the bottom of the hair line. A little messiness typically makes it prettier.
